item.title: Organizations as Agents of Social and Systemic Integration: Contradiction and Reconciliation Through Loose Demographic Coupling and Community Anchoring (under review)
Reframing the Community: How Member Participation Shifts in the Face of Spatial Change (under review)
item.description:
Abstract: How is communal participation sustained in the face of change? I draw on the case of a collegiate religious fellowship that moved online during the COVID-19 pandemic to examine how individualsâ€™ participation patterns evolve their community undergoes a collective shift.

Membersâ€™ participation trajectories were puzzling: core members moved on while periphery members moved in, often becoming core members. I explain this puzzle through the process of reframing, wherein individuals craft working lenses that answer the question â€œwhat does this community mean to me now?â€ This temporal focus reveals that those with the most positive frames (of the community as â€œbeautifulâ€) before the shift struggled most to adapt, reframing the group as â€œnot what it once was.â€

By contrast, periphery members with ambivalent frames prior to the shift came to reframe the group as beautiful, leading them to deepen their engagement. These findings have relevance for member participation in a variety of communal contexts as well as theorizing on framing more broadly.

item.title: Diversity as a Civil Religion
Street Smarts and Org Charts: Professional Expertise and The Production of Urban Integration (under review)
Predicting the Onset, Evolution and Postgraduate Impact of College Activism
item.description:
Abstract: The topics of differential recruitment to activism and its longer-term impacts have generated substantial empirical research. Yet, the lack of longitudinal studies of movement participation have limited our understanding of individual activismâ€™s dynamics over time.

Here, we use six years of longitudinal survey data and two waves of interview data from a class of college students before, throughout, and after college to examine predictors of variation in college activism, the ebb and flow of activism over the course of college, and the effect of college activism on activism two years post-graduation.

Our findings dispute one consistent empirical claim in social movement studies and confirm another. Counter to the scholarly finding on the weak impact of predisposition on recruitment, we find that predisposition powerfully predicts variation in college activism.

Consistent with the claim that significant early activism is linked with future activism, we find that studentsâ€™ activism at the end of college significantly predicts their engagement in activism after graduation.

item.title: San Francisco Bay Area: A Left Coast Metropolis Grapples with Technocracy and Inequality
item.description:
Abstract: How do civic organizations in the San Francisco Bay Area straddle the paradox of challenging entrenched inequalities in an ostensibly progressive region that has been transformed by tech-driven wealth? Local nonprofits face the tension of maintaining access to elite resources while building connections to distribute those resources and navigate divides between the haves and have-nots.

We draw on original data collected over the course of two decades on a representative sample of Bay Area nonprofit organizations. With rich information from both quantitative and qualitative data, we examine different aspects of nonprofitsâ€™ relationship to their constituents and environments, including their community embeddedness, cross-sector collaborations, and engagement in advocacy.

We then turn to the internal operations of these organizations and survey the professional backgrounds of nonprofit leaders and the usage of practices that purportedly make nonprofits more professional, accountable, and digitally savvy. Our findings reveal a sector that is developing its own model of what community-directed management looks like, neither tethered strictly to a Left Coast ethos nor displaying uniform responses to strong institutional pressures.

Although the Bay Area sector pursues heterogeneous approaches to repairing social ruptures, there is a consistent theme of rebuilding and re-creating community. We argue that the regionâ€™s diversity in values, practices, and orientations stems from fighting deep fractures that resist simple solutions in a place marked by paradox.

Â

item.title: Up-playing Difference: The Micro-foundations of Inclusion in Group Life
Organizations and Their Significant Others: Collective Identity as a Dialogic Process
Semiotic Shifts: How Culture Shapes Religious Studentsâ€™ Navigation of a Secular Institution (under review)
item.description:
Abstract: A central debate in cultural sociology is how culture shapes action. I advance scholarship on this question by theorizing how strategies of action evolve in the face of semiotic shifts, which occur when people enter institutional contexts and encounter new meanings for their preexisting beliefs.

I draw on two years of ethnographic fieldwork and 49 interviews with conservative Protestant students attending an elite, secular university to empirically demonstrate how variation in forms of religious culture links to divergent strategies of action.

When religion takes the form of common sense, the dominant institutional culture brings about a semiotic shift and studentsâ€™ distance from and reckon with their faith.

When religion takes the form of tradition, religious subculture brings about a semiotic shift and students bridge secular and religious meanings and spaces. Finally, when religion takes the form of ideology, students reject new semiotic axes and burrow into religious subcultures.

Bringing cultural and institutional theorizing into dialogue, this paper deepens our understanding of how culture matters as individuals learn to navigate new organizational contexts.

item.title: Leading The Way: Examining the Influence of Meaningful Work on Leadership (under review)
From Bat Mitzvah to the Bar: Religious Habitus, Self-Concept, and Womenâ€™s Educational Outcomes
item.description:
Abstract: This study considers the role of religious habitus and self-concept in educational stratification. We follow 3,238 adolescents for 13 years by linking the National Study of Youth and Religion to the National Student Clearinghouse.

Survey data reveal that girls with a Jewish upbringing have two distinct postsecondary patterns compared to girls with a non-Jewish upbringing, even after controlling for social origins: (1) they are 23 percentage points more likely to graduate college, and (2) they graduate from much more selective colleges. We then analyze 107 interviews with 33 girls from comparable social origins interviewed repeatedly between adolescence and emerging adulthood. Girls raised by Jewish parents articulate a self-concept marked by ambitious career goals and an eagerness to have new experiences.

For these girls, elite higher education and graduate school are central to attaining self-concept congruence. In contrast, girls raised by non-Jewish parents tend to prioritize motherhood and have humbler employment aims. For them, graduating from college, regardless of its prestige, is sufficient for self-concept congruence.

We conclude that religious subculture is a key factor in educational stratification, and divergent paths to self-concept congruence can help explain why educational outcomes vary by religion in gendered ways.

Received media coverage from: The Washington Post, Tulane News, Cornell Chronicle, NewsWise, Phys.org, Futurity, The Jewish Press, The Jerusalem Post, Reddit (Front Page), Jewish Telegraphic Agency, Religion News Service, and Rocket News.

Â

item.title: Meaning-Making at Work: Toward an Integrative Review and Framework
Bridge: The pursuit of commitment across lines of difference
item.description:
My book dissertation explores the process of cultivating civic commitments across lines of difference within an institution that shapes American society: prestigious research universities.

Through two ethnographic cases â€“ a progressive nonprofit for marginalized students and a Pentecostal campus ministry â€“ I trace the experiences of students who see themselves as strangers on campus and navigate strangerhood through their participation in communal, identity-based groups.

Drawing on four years of fieldwork and 100 interviews with students, recent graduates, and organizational staff, I explore how studentsâ€™ beliefs and moral commitments evolve, how they sustain rare identities through participation in communal groups, and the practical challenges they face trying to build inclusive organizations.

item.title: How organizations relate to their environments
item.description:
As a member of the Civic Life of Cities lab, my colleagues and I are studying how nonprofits relate to their urban environments in cities across the world (San Francisco, Seattle, Shenzhen, Sydney, Singapore, and Vienna).

Fellow team-member, Christof Brandtner and I are writing a series of papers that examine the mechanisms by which organizations produce integration in their urban environments. Sociologists have found that the density of nonprofits influences urban outcomes, but there is a lack of clarity on how and why this happens.

We theorize a critical distinction between the organizational production of social integration (connecting people to one another) and systemic integration (connecting people to complex systems, such as the economy or politics). We then examine the organizational practices that enable the production of each.

In our first paper, which is under review, we identify two modal forms of expertise (street-level and suite-level expertise, embodied by staff and volunteers) that shape organizational capacity to produce social and systemic integration, respectively.

In our second paper, an invited submission to the RSO volume, Sociological Thinking in Contemporary Organizational Sholarship, we theorize the internal processes that enable organizations pursue both forms of integration simultaneously: loose demographic coupling and communal anchoring. This paper advances work at the intersection of organizations and inequality by revealing how inequalities are justified in nonprofits, as women and minorities are relegated to the underpaid but morally valorized work of â€œcommunity building.â€ A draft can be shared upon request.

item.title: Ambiguous Credentials: How Learners Use and Make Sense of Massively Open Online Courses
item.description:
Abstract: Researchers have investigated the demography and styles of engagement of those who enroll in MOOCs but have lent little attention to how learners navigate MOOCsâ€™ ambiguity as academic certifications.

Analyzing semi-structured interviews with 60 people who devoted substantial time to at least one MOOC between 2014â€“2017, we find that people use MOOCs to build skills for application at work and home, build relationships, navigate life transitions, and enhance formal presentations of self, at the same time that they disagree on the meaning of MOOC completions as official academic accomplishments.

Our findings build theory on the multi-dimensional character of credential prestige that can inform educational social scientists and credential providers in an increasingly complicated postsecondary ecosystem.

Â

item.title: Civic identities and participation
item.description:
In an article under review (PDF available here), I theorize how communal participation is sustained in the face of change, using the case of a religious community that shifted to a remote format during the coronavirus pandemic and highlighting the process of reframing in driving participation patterns.

In an article published in Mobilization, my colleagues and I draw on a longitudinal, mixed-methods study to show how predisposition and social movement involvement in college intersect to shape trajectories of activism and civic engagement over time.

item.title: Purpose and Coping With Adversity: A Repeated Measures, Mixed-Methods Study With Young Adolescents
item.description:
Abstract: Purpose in life is associated with positive outcomes following adversity, but the mechanisms of this relationship are unclear. In this repeated measures, mixed-methods study, we examined the relationship of purpose to coping with adversity among young adolescents.

A sample of 1357 adolescents completed a survey about purpose, negative life events, and positive reframing coping four times at six month intervals. A sub-sample of 91 survey respondents participated in an interview. Surveys were analyzed using fixed-effects and mixed-effects modeling to test the relationship between purpose and coping over time. Interviews were analyzed for purpose, adversity, and coping to understand this relationship as perceived by the participant.

Survey results indicate that purpose and positive reframing coping are related and change together over time. Interview results suggest that purpose can be a response to negative experiences.

There are likely underlying factors or processes driving the relationship between purpose and positive reframing coping. Some of the potential underlying factors and processes are discussed.

item.title: A Perfect Mess: The Unlikely Ascendency of American Higher Education
How culture shapes action
item.description:
I examine how culture and meaning-making shape individual, social, and organizational outcomes in multiple independent and collaborative projects.

In my paper, â€œSemiotic Shifts,â€ I advance existing debates in cultural sociology by theorizing how strategies of action evolve in the face of semiotic shifts, which occur when people enter institutional contexts and encounter new meanings for their beliefs. I theorize three modal strategies that people adopt in the face of semiotic shifts â€“ distancing, bridging, and burrowing. I find that these strategies are linked to the cultural forms that studentsâ€™ beliefs embodied prior to college (as common sense, tradition, and ideology). This paper is under review (PDF available here).

In a collaborative paper recently published in American Sociological Review, we use mixed methods to show how religious habitus shapes educational outcomes, especially for women. We argue that Jewish women grow up in religious cultural contexts that shape their self-concepts (and the centrality of higher education and career), which helps explain religious differences in vertical and horizontal stratification in educational attainment.

With Elizabeth Trinh, we are studying how nonprofit leaders strive to cultivate meaningful work environments and draw on personal sources of meaning to do so. Our first paper received a revise and resubmit from Administrative Science Quarterly. A draft is available upon request.

Finally, in an article published in the Journal of Higher Education, my colleagues and I theorize how people interpret and utilize ambiguous credentials, using the case of massively open online courses (a low-status credential offered by high-status universities). We reveal the risks and opportunities faced by learners seeking to leverage ambiguous credentials in the labor market.
